abstract: Charles M Blow Op-Ed column recalls death of his cousin Larry, who was targeted and murdered as a black gay man in Louisiana; argues that like many others, Larry suffered repercussions of a double 'otherness' that has long inspired a particular type of hatred; laments his cousin did not live to witness Supreme Court's affirmation of same-sex marriage, on same day that a black president publicly eulogized a black man killed out of racial hatred.
lead_paragraph: For people who were both black and gay, obstacles were everywhere in years past.

headline.main: My Murdered Cousin Had a Name
headline.print_headline: My Murdered Cousin Had a Name

snippet: For people who were both black and gay, obstacles were everywhere in years past.

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
keywords.name: subject
